> Hi Martin, yes I think actually from my understanding of biology that bil=
ateral symmetry in the human line, which starts with the flatworm long ago,=
 was indeed evolved from an earlier radial symmetry.  But my point is more =
about how a regularity (or irregularity) was *preserved* as opposed to how =
it was *achieved*. No matter how a particular organizational principle come=
s about (now I'm being more careful to avoid suggesting it's more or less r=
egular than before), the problem is that there is no reason for evolution t=
o reward and thereby preserve it in an objective setting when it's first di=
scovered.  So whether or not bilateral symmetry comes from a reduction in r=
egularity or an increase in regularity, if the first bilaterally symmetric =
individual does not look very close to the final objective (and it most lik=
ely does not) then it is likely to be selected out and lost by an objective=
-driven search.

This is now going to be slightly off-topic, but I would li=
ke to add the following thoughts to your response: 
I also see the problem =
that certain organizational principles (OPs) are hard to establish when the=
ir advantage becomes only apparent in the long run (if at all). Nevertheles=
s, I think that the starting position of an evolutionary process can facili=
tate or prevent the emergence of certain OPs. For example, starting with ra=
dial symmetry, I could imagine that the amount of possibilities to reduce s=
ymmetry offers far more chances to establish asymmetric patterns than the r=
eduction from an asymmetric structure to a symmetric one. 

Martin
